fields.Title of Contribution: <p>Examining Adverse Childhood Experiences, Sexual Behaviors, and<br>Condom Use among Undergraduate College Students</p>
fields.Journal: Boston Congress of Public Health Review
fields.Description/Abstract: <p>Background<br>Understanding sexual behavior and its determinants among college students is crucial for<br>promoting sexual health and well-being. Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) may play<br>a role in shaping sexual behaviors. The current study investigates the association<br>between ACEs, condom use frequency, demographics, and consensual sexual intercourse<br>among undergraduate college students.<br>Methods<br>Upon IRB approval, a paper survey was administered among undergraduate college<br>students enrolled in the Health Promotion and Education classes at a midwestern urban<br>campus. A total of 152 participants were recruited through convenient sampling. Results:<br>A univariate regression analysis was conducted to examine the association between<br>sexual intercourse and categories of ACEs, age, condom use frequency, racial/ethnic<br>identity, sexual orientation and sex assigned at birth. Age, condom use frequency, racial/<br>ethnic identity as Asian and Caucasian were significant at p < 0.05. Furthermore, a final<br>logistic regression model was significant (χ² = 127.740, df = 4, p < .001). Participant age<br>and racial/ethnic identity as Caucasian emerged as significant in the model.<br>Discussion<br>The findings of this study encourage universities to expand their focus beyond traditional<br>socio-demographic and educational factors when addressing risky sexual behaviors<br>among college students. It highlights that ACEs may be a lingering influence driving<br>sexual activity, suggesting that trauma-informed, tailored approaches can more<br>effectively promote safe practices and address diverse student needs.</p>
